Super proud moment for me when my parents recently visited Shoffr's new HQ office in Indiranagar - and they not only loved the space but were also proud of how far we've come along! :)

Starting any business is about taking risk and plunging into the unknown - but it's really different for everyone. Willingness to take risk vs. ability to take risk are two different things - and not everyone has the same ability to take risks because we all come from different backgrounds and with different constraints.

I've probably always had high willingness to take risk, but I've also been lucky to have parents and family who have been supportive throughout and ultimately provided me with the ability to take risks. Parents who are financially independent. Two elder brothers who are successful and with steady jobs that act as a shield should anything bad come to pass. Not everyone is this lucky.

When I was frustruated few months into my first job at Goldman Sachs, my parents encouraged me to leave if I wasn't learning and to come back home. Same for all other moves I've made in my career and life. Having a home to fall back to if things go wrong, having the comfort that you won't be ridiculed for taking chances that didn't work out - these things boost your ability to take risks, and I admit that I've been luckier than most.

If I didn't have this backing in my life, it's fair to say that I wouldn't have been able to start and build Shoffr. Nor would I have been able to quit jobs without having another job in hand, nor take career breaks and have the experiences that've shaped my thinking and made me who I am today.

This one is for my parents and my family - thank you! I wouldn't have been able to even try to do all this without your love and support ❤️

posts.content:
Extremely disappointed to see cartel-style bullying tactics employed by Razorpay, Cashfree Payments, PhonePe and Paytm in their relationship with JUSPAY and merchants. Certainly did not expect the flagbearers of Indian fintech to actively work to reduce customer choices and interoperability in the payments ecosystem.

No concrete reasoning has been offered since none exists beyond creating vendor lock-in. If your product is sooo good, you should be able to convince customer to work directly - no need to sever from Juspay. The "Juspay isn't transparent" argument is too facile to even acknowledge - a smoke screen to hide the blatantly obvious power grab.

Juspay and other orchestration systems offer merchants the power and freedom to determine the best choices for themselves. This move takes away exactly that.

The bigger players will invariably go back to implementing orchestration in house (as they used to do before Juspay), and the smaller merchants will be locked in to whichever provider they are forced to choose, with a high cost of switching and no course to optimizations.

Shoffr just launched in Delhi, and I want to spend my time and energy building stuff for our new guests. Instead, I'm stuck dealing with payment provider shenanigans for no reason at all.

Last week while I was in Bangalore, I discovered a new EV fleet company called Vozi Cabs..

Vozi Cabs has done 125,000 trips in 12 months of operations starting from Bangalore; for those of us who stay in NCR, Vozi Cabs is similar to BluSmart (a managed EV-only fleet).

Vozi’s model works, they are profitable & is quite interesting:

(1) Focus on B2B mobility 🚖 
- Vozi is partnered with Ola to power airport ride bookings & MoveInSync for corporate travel
- This B2B model is similar to what Evera Cabs is doing in Delhi-NCR (with OTA platforms)
- These trips are quite profitable (BLR airport distance to city center is ≥ 40kms & it is possible to charge a premium)

(2) Use of 3rd party capital to finance vehicles 💸 
- Vozi is partnered with PNB Bank & others to secure loans to lease its Tigor EV fleet
- It also allows folks like you & me to lease the vehicles to them (this is a standard asset backed security). I’ve seen BluSmart partner with GripInvest to offer such investment opportunities

(3) Also has a B2C business 📱 
- You can book airport travel & inter-city travel

🧠 Vozi began operations in early 2023 & it seems to have picked up on the right lessons:
(a) EV fleet mobility is all about sweating the asset
- Hence, operating longer distance routes (e.g. airport commutes) are profitable
(b) EV fleet economics work if you can either charge a premium OR maintain a high # of billable hours
- Vozi is focused on B2B (i.e. corporate mobility) or inter-city rentals; both of which have a high # of billable hours

💡 As I’ve mentioned in the past, it seems like EV Mobility in India is becoming a localized play: Snap-E Cabs in Kolkata, Cab-E Mobility in Mumbai, Vozi & Shoffr in Bangalore and BluSmart and Uber Green in a few markets.

I wrote about a similar business (Kolkata’s Snap-E Mobility) here: https://lnkd.in/dgQ4hRp8

➡ Quite bullish about such local businesses & it is great to see India’s EV revolution take roots across the country.

posts.content:
If you stay in Bangalore, you would have noticed that a number of black taxis with the logo “Uber Black” have started to appear.

Uber Black is the “OG” ride — back when Uber launched its beta in May 2010, you could book a luxury black cab.. This model changed in April ‘13 when ride-sharing (i.e. non-taxi cabs) became the norm…

Now, regarding Uber Black in India:

(1) In Sept ‘24, Uber India re-launched Uber Black — starting with Mumbai.

(2) Back in 2013, when Uber launched in India, Uber Black was the initial product but in a slightly different format → it meant luxury sedans from Mercedes, Audi and BMW which were available to book.

(3) Uber Black is offered by Uber’s fleet partners (e.g. Everest Fleets where it is an investor) i.e. it is a managed fleet services and not a DCO (driver cum owner) model like the regular Ubers

(4) Uber India describes this as the “ business class of back seats” → you get a “quiet mode” option, temperature control etc from your mobile phone

(5) The Uber Black fleet consists of SUVs and MUVs from Toyota and MG. You can also book rentals (fixed hour / fixed distance).

💡Uber India has been tacking the cancellation / quality problem by slowing shifting from the DCO model to the managed fleet model — Uber Black is the 2nd instance, Uber Green is the 1st instance..

Note: Uber Black & Uber Green are examples of “managed fleets” because these 3rd party fleet operators work very closely with Uber. From my experience testing Uber Black: The way I see it → Uber Green == BluSmart, Uber Black == Blusmart Premium.

🧠The choice of vehicles is also smart → SUVs tend to have more boot space (this was a major criticism of BluSmart in early 2023 — until they rolled out the MGs). This will let Uber capture some wallet share of the lucrative airport commute market.

One could say this is the result competition from BluSmart, Shoffr & other EV fleets etc — but it is admirable to see a company at Uber’s scale respond to ground realities.

➡️ It is fascinating to see how in the past ~3 years, mobility in India is slowing moving away from “marketplace” model & closer to the “OG Meeru model” i.e. managed fleets.

BluSmart, once considered a cleaner, premium alternative to ride-hailing companies like Ola and Uber, has ceased new ride bookings in Delhi-NCR and Bengaluru due to the proceedings of SEBI’s investigation into financial misconduct. 

Amid the turmoil, Kislay Verma, the founder of Shoffr, a Bengaluru-based premium car service provider, has quickly seized the opportunity, responding to frustrated users complaining about the sudden unavailability of the BluSmart service.

To this, the Shoffr founder replied, “Our team at @shoffr_in would be honoured to serve your parents. Let us know when they need a ride next time.”

Verma responded to several other users as well.

The electric cab service was quickly rising as an alternative in India’s metro cities.

The app, though available on the Play Store, now shows no available time slots or booking dates, effectively pausing its operations without an official statement.

BluSmart’s parent company, Gensol Engineering Ltd (GEL), faces serious allegations from SEBI.

In an interim order, SEBI accused promoters Anmol Singh Jaggi and Puneet Singh Jaggi of taking loans for the company and then diverting and misusing the funds.

Goodbye OLA & UBER.

Say hello to BluSmart & Shoffr!

EV startups like BluSmart and Shoffr are disrupting Ola and Uber in India’s ride-hailing market.

But why EVs?

Because they create the margins that enable this disruption to happen.

Every single ride in an EV happens at a much lower cost compared to an ICE vehicle.

The lower cost ensures that EV firms can price themselves as Ola/Uber but operate at a fraction of their costs.

They have a promising strategy, too.

BluSmart:
In 2019, BluSmart, founded by Anmol Jaggi, Punit K Goyal, Tushar Garg, Anirudh Arun, & Rishabh Sood, entered the market, challenging conventions with its all-electric cab service. Focusing on providing an eco-friendly, reliable, and economical alternative to traditional ride-hailing.

Shoffr:
Started in November 2022 when Vikas Bardia, and Kislay Verma came together to redefine taxi services in Bangalore. With a vision of setting the gold standard for cab rides, dedicated to ensuring comfort and convenience.

But what are the key aspects that contribute to their success:

1.Punctuality and Communication: On-time pick-ups without the need for location confirmation calls demonstrate reliability and efficiency.

2.Quality Fleet: Offering a BYD EV SUV as a standard option represents a commitment to providing a premium and environmentally conscious ride.

3.Clean and Well-Maintained Vehicles: The emphasis on cleanliness and regular servicing reflects a dedication to ensuring a comfortable and hygienic experience for passengers.

4.Customer Assistance: The driver's proactive approach in assisting with luggage adds a personal touch, making the experience feel more like having a chauffeur.

5.Route Customization: Providing options for toll-road or alternate routes based on passenger preferences shows a commitment to accommodating individual needs.

6.Transparent Payment Process: Despite the initial skepticism about paying the full fee upfront, the transparency in the payment process appears to contribute to a seamless experience.

Positive experience and assistance with Seamless operations management are a testament to the impact of exceptional customer service.

It's indeed true that customer referrals play a vital role in the growth and success of businesses, especially in the service industry.

So, do you recognize this branded of cabs from Bangalore?

Probably because Uber & Ola have dropped our expectations so low that anything marginally better is a great experience.🤣

But jokes aside, these two were just a perfect match for comfort and convenience.❤️

It's clear that BluSmart & Shoffr has successfully created a service that resonates with customers and goes beyond the expectations set by other ride-hailing platforms.

Wishing BluSmart & Shoffr continued success in providing outstanding service to its customers!

For a slight premium (~50% extra viz Uber), you could book a chauffer driven airport transfer into the city. You feel like a King, and no surprises, the company does ~ $100M in annual bookings in just ~3 years of starting!!

Found out a few interesting facts about Wheely & its global peers:

(1) About Wheely 🛬

Recently Shoffr announced $1 million in funding from a 'user-only' community, an unusual route for raising investments. 

For context, Shoffr offers premium/luxury ride-hailing services for airport rides in Bengaluru, selected intercity trips, and rentals with all-electric BYD SUV cars.

They started hyper-locally with just two cars focused on BLR airport rides and scaled profitably to $1.5 million ARR with 75 cars in 15 months while remaining bootstrapped.

It's interesting why they chose to start with airport rides:
- BLR airport's cab market is a $145 million market and one of the most profitable and predictable routes (as per Ken).
- Ride-hailing is a chicken-and-egg problem with supply and demand. By keeping the destination fixed, they can work on demand predictability and build the supply (drivers and EVs) accordingly.

I have been a frequent user for all my BLR airport rides, and here are my observations:
- Generally 15-20% higher priced than their peers (Uber, Ola SUV segments) but No surge pricing, so during peak hours, it will be similar pricing.
- Cars are super clean and offer you a feeling of luxury.
- So far all bookings are through website. It's a simple website that handles the booking.
- Drivers are extremely polite.
- Drivers' incentives are based on customer ratings.
- They also have the option to include pets in traveling (with additional charges).

Things that inspired me as a business model
- The founder himself used to handle customer service support to stay closer to customers.
- Probably 100% of business is driven by word-of-mouth and high retention cohorts. 
- Taking conscious and well researched call before any growth plans which makes business sense (choosing EV car maker, route plans, hiring etc.) 
- Scaling and growing without losing the sight on the customer satisfaction and profitability
- Saying NO to things that doesn't align with the Shoffr's vision and values.

As Vikas quotes in his investment announcement post - 'Shoffr is neither just a dhandha nor just a startup - it's an attempt to take the best of both and build a new-age business.'

Certainly, Shoffr is an unconventional business, turning the tables of a high capex business to a lean, sustainable one with a strong focus on customer satisfaction, operating margin, and profitability from day one, setting gold standards in the ecosystem.

You can also read the investment memo by Rahul Mathur, who has detailed the business model, TAM, revenue, growth plans, and risks - https://lnkd.in/gvDDqZjk

If you are traveling to/from BLR airports, you should definitely give Shoffr a try.

Last week, Uber India invested a further $30M into Everest Fleets (the company which operates Uber Green)

Everest was valued at ~$425M in this round; and it is believed that IFC may invest a further ~$20M — bringing the Series C total investment to ~$50M.. This is a company worth spending some time studying:

(1) The Uber <> Everest Fleet relationship 🤝

- Everest Fleet Pvt. Ltd. had traditionally provided an ICE fleet to Uber; back in 2023, per the company, ~80% of their 10K vehicles were operating on Uber’s platform
- Uber is doubling down on its investment & strategic partnership in a big way: In June 2023, Uber India infused ~$20M into Everest Fleets. 

PS: Like I said a year ago, we like to believe most Ubers are DCO (Driver Cum Owners) but in reality they are fleet vehicles run by proper companies (like Everest) which provide the stable supply

(2) About Everest Cabs 🤔

- It is a Mumbai headquartered fleet business started in 2016 by Siddharth Ladsariya (who is a prolific Angel investor & owner of a manufacturing unit)
- Everest is profitable: ₹41 crore of PAT in FY 23 (FY24 PAT is not known; but FY 24 revenue was ~₹1,000 crore which is > x2 the FY 23 revenue of ~₹460 crore)
- Everest has an interesting model wherein 2/3rds of vehicles are leased using the firm’s own money & 1/3rd of vehicles are leased from 3rd party investors (like you & me) — this is a model which even Blusmart uses

(3) Everest is Uber’s “weapon” against BluSmart & other managed fleet models ⚔️

- Running an EV fleet requires heavy CAPEX — something which BluSmart, Shoffr & other managed fleets have taken on
- Uber is using its relationship with Everest to offer a managed fleet experience (Uber Green) as an alternative to BluSmart & others.
- Uber India has done a fab job of tackling the “innovators dilemma” here :)

PS: For those curious, a conservative profit estimate for FY24 might be ~₹80 crore (or ~$10M) which means this round of financing ascribes a PE of ~42.5 times. This is a bit higher than its listed peer (albeit slightly different model) - WTiCabs (which trades at ~28 PE). But, Everest has a much larger fleet (~17.7K vehicles versus 8K of WTiCabs)

➡️Everest Cabs had taken an ambitious target of building an EV fleet of ~10K vehicles by 2026. The company has raised ~₹550 crore in debt financing from multiple institutions like Kotak Mahindra, SIDBI, ICICI Bank etc (has a BBB+ credit rating).

Sid & team have built a fantastic business — given their earliest investor Artha Venture Fund a great partial exit. Godspeed 🚀

(a) How do you get to unit break even? (i.e. drive high utilization OR premium pricing OR both)
(b) How do you scale from YY to YYY? (i.e. don’t have too many quality issues at x10 scale)
(c) OEM risk? (i.e. will the preferred OEM continue to drop prices? And, will battery life pan out?)

Tesla is launched in India, and the Model Y costs you 'just' Rs. 60 lakh.....But, the real cost of owning this is Rs. 208/km...Should I buy or not?

This morning, I read the news that @Tesla has finally opened its first showroom in #Mumbai.

Like so many of us, I got excited. It's Electric, Sexy, Sustainable. The Tesla badge. But here’s a question in my mind:

Is buying a Tesla Model Y in India actually worth it? Or are you better off just booking an Ola/Uber/Shoffr SUV and letting someone else deal with our traffic madness?

So, the analyst in me quickly ran with a few numbers...

Let’s say you buy a Tesla Model Y for Rs 60 lakh and drive it for 15 years, clocking 1.5 lakh km. (Indian conditions)

- Tesla Y Model in India: Rs 60,00,000
 - Charging cost (avg Rs 7/unit): Rs 1,65,000
 - Total spend = Rs 61,65,000

That works out to Rs 41.10 per km.
(And that’s before you even factor in insurance, tyres, or surprise repairs.)

Now, make a note, it's you who would be in the driving seat...So additional investment of your time.

Here’s the thing… driving in India can feel like a full-time job:

- Endless traffic
- Horns blaring
- Road rage lurks around every corner
- Parking nightmares

You must be earning at least Rs 80 lakh per annum to buy such a car...Factor 8 hours working, 20 working days a month for 15 years, 1.5 Lakh Km driving at avg 25km/hr speed. (Indian condition).

Your TRUE COST PER KM to own a Tesla Y Model, including your time, is insane ....Rs 208/km !!!

Just take an Ola/Uber/Shoffr, instead?

Hop into an Ola / Uber SUV for ~Rs 25–35/km, or book a premium Shoffr ride for ~Rs 50–70/km (As I do, and take on Rent for 4-6 hours to avoid P2P booking hassle).

Sit in the back seat, sip your coffee, and utilize the same time to finish a few important calls while being on the road. 

Cheery on the Cake - No Rs 60 lakh upfront. No resale headache. No Maintenance, No frequent  Charging...........and most importantly - no stress behind the wheel.

So… Buy or Don’t Buy?

I personally feel that if you love driving, want to make a statement, and have the cash, then Tesla is tempting.

If you’d rather save your time, sanity, and cash flow, then stick with cabs and let someone else handle the chaos.

Because while Rs 41/km on papers is already on the higher side, the real cost is much higher....Rs 208/km.... that makes even premium chauffeur rides look like a bargain.

Buying a Tesla Model Y in India isn’t just about money, it’s about time. If you love driving and it’s your therapy, maybe it’s worth it.

But if you’d rather want to invest that Rs 60 Lakh in an appreciating asset and spend those 6,000 hours living life, building your career, or being with your family… Ola, Uber, or Shoffr might be the smarter choice.

☑️In 2024 itself, we’ve seen some notable examples of the C&C round:

(1) Shoffr (EV Mobility | $1M Pre-Seed) - entirely from its customers

(2) BONOMI (D2C Brands | < $500K Pre-Seed) - entirely from Twitter friends & customers

PS: I'm a big fan of all 3 founders - Vardhman from BONOMI, Vikas from Shoffr and Pritesh from Pneucons.

And, I’d bet Mlada (D2C Brands | Women’s Fashion) might also go down the same route IFF they decide to raise 3rd party money

🧠Few important points to understand about the C&C round:

(1) The amount of money raised here is much more (>> $300K) than what a typical Friends & Family round involves (<< $150K)
(2) Therefore, the C&C round is somewhat competitive to a micro-VC
(3) And, unlike an F&F round, a C&C round also has “complete outsiders” (e.g. customers of the product who the Founder may not even know by name) 
(4) C&C rounds are mostly a deliberate attempt by the Founder to raise non-institutional money (i.e. VCs may want to invest but the Founder isn’t keen to take their money)

⚠️Now, some legal caveats on the C&C round:

(a) The investments are made through RUVs (Roll Up Vehicles) sponsored by AIFs (regulated investment entities)

(b) Therefore, all the individual investors in the C&C round need to satisfy SEBI guidelines for private market investing (the sponsor AIFs make sure this is adhered to)

(c) Naturally, the pricing & terms of such rounds are led by the Founder (due to the lack of an institution). And, the company may not undergo as deep a DD as when an institution is involved.

➡️ I’d expect to see more and larger C&C rounds (especially in Consumer Brands & other tangible products) in the coming days. As someone said: “Why should the institutional chaps have all the fun?”

When you think about an EV fleet in India - you might have this image of a BluSmart fleet full of the standard Tata Tigor EVs. 

And, you’re not alone - most of us are now accustomed to travelling via Tata Tigor EVs. BUT, will this remain true in the future?

📊 Let’s look at India’s EV 4 wheeler data from 2023:

(1) Tata Motors closed with 60K sales viz 32K in 2022
(2) MG India closed with 9.5K sales viz 3.5K in 2022
(3) BYD India closed with 2K sales viz 0.3K in 2022

Note: There are some others like Citroën but the above 3 have been pushing for sales into fleet operators which is the focus today. 

Although Tata Motors is still the 1st by a HUGE margin; its market share has fallen from ~80% to 70%. Let’s go into the micro:

(a) In 2023, MG India supplied 500 EV SUVs to BluSmart alone
-i.e. ~ 1/10th of BluSmart’s EV fleet is this SUV (which you can book via the Premium rides on longer routes / airport commutes)

(b) At end of 2023, BYD delivered ~50 EVs to Shoffr (EV fleet in BLR)
- BYD had earlier planned to invest ~$1bn into local production capability - BUT this was rejected by the GOI.

💡 Now, we all have this romantic idea of a fleet with a single vehicle type - which is driven by our fascination with airline LCCs (Low Cost Carriers) e.g. Indigo Airlines & the Airbus A320 and Southwest Airlines & Boeing 737..

IF you read BluSmart’s app reviews - you’ll quickly realize that a “one size fits all” cab does NOT make sense. Have you travelled with a family & luggage to the airport in a Tigor EV? You’d need to sit on your bags (even if you can do that)..

🧠 Hence, MG India & other players have a huge opportunity to break into the fleet segment with vehicles larger than a sedan e.g. a premium SUV like the MG ZS… Although Tata Motors has its Nexon EV variant - I have seen this in any fleets (as yet, but happy to be corrected)

➡ So here’s the broad contours for competition in sales to the EV fleet:

- Short distance / economy commute hatchback: Tata Motor’s Tiago will face competition from MG’s Comet
- Medium distance commute sedan: Tata Motors has the clear lead
- Long distance / premium commute SUV: Tata Motors needs to break MG’s lead here

And, most fleet operators will mix & match across OEMs to ensure they don’t have a supply chain disruption risk.

Sadly, BYD is out of the race right now due to its plant permissions NOT being provided; MG & Tata Motors build the EVs locally..

➡ Therefore, my bet is that by end of 2024 - we’ll see Tata & MG become the top 2 contenders of EV fleet sales in India. It won’t just be a Tata world!

Asian Development Bank, Companion Capital, and current #investors Green Frontiers Capital and LC Nueva also contributed to the money raise. This comes as Omidyar Network, the #fund founded by eBay founder Pierre Omidyar, prepares to leave India after more than a decade in the nation.

According to Aggarwal, Revfin has raised Rs 280 crore in debt this year, which it would largely utilize to provide loans and expand its #business. It is now trying to raise Rs 500 crore in debt over the next three to six months, he said.

Revfin has so far raised Rs 625 crore, of which Rs 450 crore is debt. Omidyar Network contributed $5 million in the most recent equity round, Companion Capital invested $3.8 million, and the Asian Development Bank invested $2.5 million.

Revfin, which operates in 23 states, will utilize the capital to expand operations, according to Aggarwal. Uber just made a bold move in India—switching from a commission-based model to a subscription-based one for autos. This means drivers now pay a flat daily fee instead of Uber taking a cut from each ride.

Let’s break it down! 👇

1️⃣ Why Did Uber Make the Switch?
💥 Market Disruption – ONDC-backed Namma Yatri charges zero commissions, forcing Uber to adapt.
 💥 Growing Competition – Rapido, BluSmart (EVs), and Shoffr are eating into Uber’s market share.
 💥 Government Push – The Indian government is promoting ONDC-based mobility, reducing dependence on private platforms.

2️⃣ Impact on Uber’s Business
💰 Before: Uber took 25% per ride (~₹250 on ₹1,000 earnings).
💰 Now: Uber charges ₹20-₹40/day—a 90% revenue drop per driver!
⚠️ Challenge: Uber needs 10x more active drivers just to break even.

3️⃣ Impact on Consumers 🚀
✅ Pros:
 ✔️ Lower fares – Drivers keep 100% of earnings.
 ✔️ Fewer cancellations – No profit-based refusals.
 ✔️ Transparent pricing – Govt-approved fares.
 ✔️ Happier drivers – More satisfied drivers = better service.

❌ Cons & Risks:
 ⚠️ Uber = Just a tech platform? – Less involvement in ride economics, weaker customer support.
 ⚠️ Who ensures safety? – Uber invested in background checks, SOS, trip tracking—but will they still own rider safety?
 ⚠️ Less support & insurance – With Uber stepping back, trip insurance and dispute resolution could weaken.

4️⃣ Uber’s Bigger Challenges in India & Beyond
🇮🇳 India:
 🚨 ONDC-backed ride-hailing threatens Uber’s dominance.
 ⚔️ Hyper-competitive market – Rapido (bikes), BluSmart (EVs) pulling premium users.
 💵 Price-sensitive market – India = just 1% of Uber’s global revenue.

🇺🇸 US:
 🚖 Self-driving car disruption – Waymo surpassing Lyft in SF, reducing reliance on gig workers.
 ⚖️ Regulatory battles – Push for driver employee benefits = higher costs.
 📉 Market saturation – Uber is profitable but future growth is uncertain.

5️⃣ What’s Next for Uber India? 🚀
💡 Hybrid model – Keep commissions for premium rides (Uber Premier, Uber XL), subscriptions for regular ones.
 🛡️ Safety subscription – Charge for verified drivers, trip insurance, & 24/7 support.
 🏛️ Govt-backed compliance – Work with regulators for driver verification & safety standards.

Is this a game-changer or a desperate move? Do check Xplainerr newsletter (in the 1st comments) where Venkatesh Gupta has simplified this piece for you.

Let’s talk about the ride-hailing market in India and why replicating Uber’s success here isn’t a smooth journey.  

In the US, Uber thrives on a Ride-sharing model with partners who are retirees or part-timers. They drive for fun, love meeting new people, and treat it as a side hustle. But here in India, it’s a whole different story. Most drivers depend entirely on this job as their primary source of income. They’re daily wage earners who work in shifts, either renting vehicles or driving for fleet owners. Their priority? Maximizing rides, not ride experience. 

Now add to this the reality of Price-sensitive Indian users. They don’t hesitate to switch platforms just to save a few bucks. This has turned the market into a commodity – everyone is offering the same ride, just with a slightly different price tag. No wonder Ola and Uber have seen a significant drop in market share as newer players like Rapido, Bluesmart, and others carve out niches like:  
- BluSmart  Trained drivers, EVs.    
- Shoffr  Premium rides.  
- Nagara Meter Auto  Metered fare rides in Bangalore.  
- QuicReach  Airport and Intercity Carpooling.  

Here’s the kicker: Ola and Uber don’t control the driver supply. They’re matchmakers at best, connecting riders to drivers like OLX connects buyers to sellers. No control over the service = no quality consistency.  

The future? Sustainable businesses with strong USPs. Think of it like airlines – Indigo focuses on low costs, Vistara (now Air India) on premium service, and they coexist beautifully. The ride-hailing space is moving in the same direction. Businesses that focus on their strengths instead of burning millions to compete on price will win.  

This is where naviget comes in. 🚀  

naviget isn’t just another ride-hailing app – we’re here to redefine the game. For riders, we simplify commuting by offering transparency and ease. For businesses, we provide a platform that eliminates the heavy lifting of user acquisition, retention, and user-side tech management. Now, businesses can focus on what they do best – building their own USPs – while naviget connects them to a larger audience.  

The market is shifting, and we’re not just keeping up; we’re leading the way. Let’s make commuting smarter, better, and more sustainable.

posts.content:
If you are in Bangalore, you would have seen cars around reading Uber Black. Uber Black is Uber's luxury ride service in India that matches riders with top-rated drivers in #premium cars.

Back in 2013, Uber launched Uber black offering ride services in premium cars from BMW, Mercedes, and Audi. In 2024, it relaunched Uber Black which consists of SUVs from Toyota and MG.

A lot of this is due to the rise of incumbent #startups like Shoffr, BluSmart Premium. Here are some interesting numbers:

- India's ride-hailing market is ~$7-12B, with airport travel $1-2 B and corporate travel another $2 B of this pie.

- Bangalore's airport transfer #market ~Rs 1500 Cr with over 30,000 trips every day

- The entire ride-hailing market is concentrated in top 10 tier cities in India

Ola, Uber disrupted the Taxi market with the DCO model( Driver Cum Owner). However, as most of us had encountered rising commissions and shrinking margins for drivers, #customerservice went for a toss due to high cancellations, extra charges, and trip denials.

The airport transfer and #corporate travel markets had always been comfort-first, and price-inelastic. That's where BluSmart and Shoffr came in with a new model in which they owned the vehicle and enhanced the customer experience. 

Since these are EV cabs, operating costs are lower. Companies have leveraged these savings to enhance customer experience. Uber Black is offered by Uber’s fleet partners, Everest Fleet taking complete ownership of the ride and not a DCO (driver cum owner) model like the regular Uber.

Uber India describes this as the “ #business class of back seats,” with features like a “quiet mode” option, temperature control, and more, all accessible from your mobile phone.

It's so interesting to see a company as big as Uber listening to on-ground feedback and launching services. Going ahead it's definitely going to eat into Shoffr and Blu Smart's market share.

For the sector, it's finally moving back from the marketplace model to the owned/ managed fleet model which existed since so many years. 

With this shift back to a fleet-owned model, do you think ride-hailing services will improve in #india? Or will new challenges arise?

The recent buzz around BluSmart's operational pause has sparked a lot of discussion, and rightly so. Their commitment to service quality undeniably set a benchmark when compared to Ola and Uber. However, we need to consider the sustainability of a business model solely focused on superior service without a clear path to profitability.

BluSmart's ability to offer premium service at comparable prices raises a crucial question: was this achieved by prioritizing user acquisition and satisfaction over long-term financial viability? The market dynamics suggest that while consumers appreciate quality, price sensitivity remains a significant factor. We can also see this with players like Shoffr, who, despite a reputation for excellent service, haven't been able to penetrate the intra-city cab market, due to their premium pricing.

This brings us to a fundamental lesson: exceptional service comes at a cost. As consumers, we must recognize that consistently demanding premium experiences at the lowest possible price can inadvertently lead to the demise of businesses striving for higher standards. Are we, as a market, willing to pay a reasonable premium for reliable and quality services, or will we continue to gravitate solely towards the cheapest option, potentially sacrificing service quality in the long run? Is this what has left us stuck with IndiGo (InterGlobe Aviation Ltd)?

P.S. My sincere empathy goes out to Punit K Goyal. It's disheartening to witness a fantastic founder potentially bearing the brunt of misaligned priorities of his partners. I hope he bounces back and continues to build impactful solutions elsewhere.

As someone who worked in return reduction for 2.5 years, I must say that fashion sees the highest percentage of returns and without the option of that customers will not order from the platform. The Q-comm platforms are experimenting both with regular pickup for returns and in-store returns in collaboration with the original merchant.

2. 𝐈𝐧𝐝𝐢𝐚𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐢𝐧𝐯𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐠𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝 Amazon 𝐚𝐧𝐝 Flipkart 𝐭𝐨 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐯𝐢𝐨𝐥𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐥𝐨𝐜𝐚𝐥 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐥𝐚𝐰𝐬. The main points in this are giving preference to specific sellers, prioritising certain listings, and steeply discounting products and in the process hurting competition. Both the platforms having "preferred sellers" meant that the sellers got warehousing and other services and minuscule costs, and their products were highlighted on top of the pages. Apart from this, Other problems listed by Competition Commission Of India have been deep discounting and exclusive product launches (mobile phones). 

3. OpenAI 𝐥𝐚𝐮𝐧𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫 𝐧𝐞𝐰 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥 𝐨1 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐩𝐚𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤𝐬 𝐛𝐞𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐭. Clean cars, timely arrivals, and the kind of calm that made people (especially seniors) feel safe.

“My parents don’t want a car or a driver. They say, ‘BluSmart hai na.’”

…it hit deeper than just a business headline.

Because at its core, mobility isn’t about tech, cars, or convenience.
It’s about care.
It’s about people trusting that someone will show up without fail.

And when that trust breaks because of investigations or mismanagement—someone needs to show up in its place. Not to compete, but to serve.

I saw Kislay Verma from Shoffr respond to a concerned user with this line:

“We’d be honoured to serve your parents.”
No pitch. Just empathy. That’s the energy this space needs more of.

At Drive Assist, we’re trying to build with the same intention.
We’re offering drivers on demand and permanent drivers, yes.
But more than that, we’re building human-first mobility—the kind that doesn’t just move people, it supports them.

Because: ✅ Trust is earned, not claimed.
✅ Good service is quiet, consistent, and caring.
✅ And people always remember how you made them feel.

To everyone wondering what comes after BluSmart—there are alternatives being built.
Not just louder. Better.

Let’s build a mobility ecosystem where trust isn’t a feature.

This story is only a few days old and still developing.

VCs sell the India story to global investors like pension and sovereign funds.

posts.content:
“It’s better to have 100 people who love you than a million who kind of like you.”

When Brian Chesky said this, he probably had no idea a ride-hailing startup in Bengaluru would bring that idea to life.

The Indian ride-hailing space, dominated by Ola, Uber, Rapido, and BlueSmart was already crowded when Shoffr entered the scene. But instead of trying to win over the whole market, they built something exceptional for a small group of frequent flyers who just wanted reliable, comfortable airport transfers.
This wasn’t just a niche. It was their minimum viable segment, the ideal starting point for their MVP.

That tight focus paid off. Shoffr hit $1.5 million in ARR and turned profitable, all with just 75 EVs and less than ₹50 lakh in equity.
Since then, they’ve expanded into hourly rentals and are slowly entering new markets like Delhi NCR.

But the real validation came in March 2024, when Shoffr raised $1.1 million from their own customers. No VCs. Just pure user love. Over 100 people invested, and nearly a third were startup founders.
That kind of trust doesn’t come from being good enough. It comes from building something people genuinely care about.

Shoffr didn’t chase mass appeal. They solved one problem incredibly well. And when it mattered most, their users backed them not just with bookings, but with belief.

That’s Brian Chesky’s quote, lived out in full.

The BluSmart Decline: A Personal Reflection

Whenever I travel to Bangalore, I book BluSmart for all my travel in the city (which is a lot) and I’ve always had the best experience with them, except this time. 

The cabs were dirty, the drivers no longer courteous and it felt like I was sitting in an Uber/Ola. It was a poor experience and as soon as I reached Jaipur, I saw an article and suddenly it all made sense.

BluSmart is facing a major leadership crisis - CEO Anirudh Arun, CTO Rishabh Sood, Chief Business Officer Tushar Garg, and VP of Experience Priya Chakravarthy have all resigned in the past week. This exodus comes amid serious financial troubles, with their parent company Gensol Engineering selling off 34% of BluSmart’s fleet (about 3,000 EVs) to manage mounting debt.

The company that once promised to revolutionize ride-hailing with clean EVs and professional service is now seeing daily rides drop to less than half what they were previously clocking. Their Dubai operations are being shut down as they scramble to stay afloat.

What’s particularly telling is how these corporate troubles directly translate to the declining customer experience I felt firsthand. Without proper maintenance budgets, the cars are deteriorating. Without leadership oversight, service standards are collapsing.

I believe this is the end of a beloved company which couldn’t scale. Their asset-heavy model that required owning both vehicles and charging infrastructure proved too capital-intensive, and now they’re paying the price for rapid expansion without sustainable unit economics.

Curious to see what kind of new companies arise here - major opportunity. Already rooting for Shoffr.

Offer exclusive discounts for concert-goers and your loyalty program members. Even at a conservative 15-20% conversion rate, ~2-2.5K AOV, thats 2 crores+ on GBV. And this is just ONE of his 10 planned India concerts!

How Rapido Beat Giants in India’s Ride-Hailing Game

While Ola and Uber chased big cities, Rapido took a different road.
It focused on bikes—not cars—and it paid off.

Drivers ❌ Captains ✅

Here's how:

1. Read the Market Right :
Rapido noticed that two-wheelers were king in India, especially in smaller cities.
Ola and Uber missed this, so Rapido seized the chance to serve an untapped market with cheaper, quicker rides.

2. Kept Costs Low :
With bikes, costs stayed lean—letting Rapido keep prices low for users in low-income areas.
That made it a no-brainer choice for people who wanted value for money.

3. Put Drivers First :
While others took hefty cuts, Rapido prioritized its drivers, offering better pay, faster payouts, and extra income options.
This approach built loyalty—drivers trusted Rapido more and stayed with them.

4. Flexible Fees :
Rapido’s fixed-fee model was a game-changer. It gave drivers stable, predictable earnings, drawing more of them to the platform.

5. Expanded to Deliveries :
By adding delivery services in non-peak hours, Rapido tapped into new revenue streams with the same fleet—doubling down on efficiency when they partnered with Swiggy and explored logistics in quick commerce.

6. Tier-2 and Tier-3 Focus :
Rapido didn’t need to fight big brands like ola and uber in major cities. Instead, it grew in smaller cities with less competition and less ad spend.
___________________________________________________________________
What’s Next?

Rapido's growth is impressive, but it still faces challenges like regulatory hurdles and scaling without losing driver and customer trust.

Well now… even Ola and Uber are into Bikes, Parcel delivery, sharing Auto and Cabs along with BluSmart, Shoffr, Zypp Electric,Yulu etc.

The Avis Rent a Car tagline "We’re number two. We try harder." was a #marketing masterstroke launched in 1962, crafted by the advertising agency Doyle Dane Bernbach (DDB). 

At the time, Avis was the second-largest car rental company in the U.S., trailing behind Hertz, the industry leader. Rather than shying away from their underdog status, Avis embraced it, turning their position into a strength. 

The campaign was rooted in the idea that being number two meant Avis had to go the extra mile to win customers - through better service, harder work, and more dedication.

The tagline came out of a meeting where DDB’s creative team, led by Helmut Krone and Bill Bernbach, pushed for honesty over exaggeration. Avis president Robert Townsend reportedly shared candid insights about the company’s operations, revealing a culture of scrappy determination. 

This inspired the campaign’s core message:

Avis wasn’t the biggest, but they’d outwork the competition to earn your business. The ads were straightforward, witty, and human - promising things like faster service, and cars in top condition.

The campaign was a massive success. Within a year, Avis went from losing $3.2 million to turning a $1.2 million profit. By 1966, their market share jumped from 11% to 16%, closing the gap with Hertz. The tagline became a cultural touchstone, resonating beyond advertising as a mantra for underdogs everywhere. It ran for 50 years until Avis retired it in 2012 for a new campaign, “It’s Your Space,” which focused on empowering customers. However, the “We Try Harder” ethos remains a defining part of Avis’s brand identity.

Vikas is building almost silently. Shoffr cabs 🚖 are BYD E6 in top condition, The liveried chauffeurs are well-spoken, well-mannered and the service is top notch.

6. EV cars, for those who care about the environment

If the dominant players in the market are not providing these basic service levels, then isn’t the void so glaringly obvious and one that has existed for eons now?

And again, we know how Blusmart started struggling with points 1, 4, and 5 as the company scaled up its operations and added more cars. So they started contributing to this void much before their sad debacle. 

The question is, with Shoffr already ticking the boxes on points 1, 3, 4, 5 (in passive form), and 6 above, how long will it take them to crack point number 2, and scale operations without compromising on each of these hygiene factors?

As someone who takes cabs at least 2-3 times a week, I would keenly be waiting for this next phase where there is an existing playbook that can be perfected (with some tweaks of course), but one with far reaching impact that could set the gold standard for this industry in times to come!

Uber One: An experiment for dynamic priced mass-premium service for the value conscious Indian users
There's a lot of debate around 'value conscious' Indian customers, and to serve them better, Uber just launched a new subscription program called 'Uber One', a mass-premium service that is more nuanced than a direct premium service competitors like Shoffr.

Quick overview of Uber one: It is offering up to 10% Uber one credits, prioirty support, zomato gold for 3 months, and top rated drivers!

To understand 'mass-premium', let's understand the user segment:
- Frequent urban commuters who use Uber 3-4 times per week
- Value-conscious professionals seeking predictable ride expenses
- Cross-platform users who utilize both rides and food delivery services

But the most interesting thing is the subscription price: Uber introduced a dynamic city-based pricing that indicates market testing. What it means is there's a different price for difference city. For Kolkata, the subscription fee is around 99 rupees/month where as in delhi it is priced around 49 rupees/month

Now Let's dig deep into this positioning to understand the intent behind 'Uber one'
- Creating a middle-market loyalty program rather than competing with ultra-premium services
- Focusing on increasing usage frequency and cross-platform adoption
- Building an ecosystem play rather than a pure premium service offering
- Targeting value-maximizing regular users rather than luxury-seeking customers

But why now? Let's understand how is Uber doing as a business? and we may get a clue!
- Record-Breaking Growth
- Uber achieved its first GAAP operating profit exceeding $1 billion
- 20% year-over-year increase in gross bookings
- 82% year-over-year growth in Adjusted EBITDA to $1.4 billion

This seems the perfect timing, right? And on top of that:
- 25 million Uber One members globally
- Global Uber One members spend 3x more than non-members
- 70% year-over-year growth in subscription base

And even on top of that, the competition is on fire:
- Rising competition from Google-backed Namma Yatri, which recently Secured $11 million in funding
- Emergence of specialized players like Rapido, which recently achieved unicorn status with $120 million funding

But as any other experiment, it has a room for improvement. Personally I would recommend:
- Pricing Strategy: Implement consistent pricing across cities to reduce confusion. Create tier-based subscription levels based on usage patterns. Offer flexible subscription periods beyond current monthly/annual options
- Product Enhancement: . Introduce city-specific benefits for different city-wise user segment rather than one-size-fits-all approach

So now you'd easily be able to spot flying taxis from your skyscrapers in Bengaluru.

Also, does it make sense?

Let's look at the unit economics.

Distance from e-city to airport is 55 kms, and it usually takes 2+ hours on any day with INR 1200+, in the range of 21/ km (Rapido/Ola/Uber w/o surge) to 26+/km (Shoffr/ Premium w/o surge)

With the aerial distance of 35-40 kms, and starting charge of INR 1700, it starts from 42/km. I doubt they'll charge 1700/- for e-city. This could be the starting price or an average price.
It's a 7-seater, so 1700*7= ~ 12k per trip.
Assuming 19 minutes is the trip with no stoppages, and 10-11 minutes of dropping and picking, we can safely assume 3 one-way trips every 2 hours.

Daily max. capacity: Terminal 1 - 70k, Terminal 2 - 40k
Assuming at least 2000 passengers, hit on a hourly basis, and 8-10% can try the flying-taxis based on distance, urgency and luggage restrictions, means for 150-200 folks, you'll see at least 10 flying taxis every hour.

Not bad, this can go upto 20 or 30 as well depending on the air traffic congestion and new policies for them.

Coming back to unit economics, for 20 taxis every hour, daily generation of revenue 12k per trip * 1.5 trips/hour * 12 hours= ~ 2.2 lacs per day, or at least 800 Cr annually.

Depending on the pilot salaries, operational expenses, airport parking & pick-up location charges, maintenance and miscellaneous, this should be recovered in 2 years if not in 1.

I'm not sure how it is going to turn out environmentally, but for sure the airport surge charges are going to reduce with the air competition for airport rides.

Thoughts?

What does the arrival of new players in the Indian app cab space mean? 

New players like Shoffr, Drive, Rapido, BluSmart and more have entered the Indian app-cab market as the need for convenience becomes ubiquitous in our lives with the growing potential of technology to meet those needs. The app cab space first emerged on identifying the inconvenience of getting a ride, and now, has gone deeper in perfecting that niche. This evolution -

1. Democratizes the app cab space challenging the dominance of hitherto major players like Ola and Uber, together with the establishment of the ONDC network across the country. 

2. Gives more choices to users and with the advantage of fair pricing, cutting through the monopoly of major players.

3. Emphasizes the need to smooth out the edges of user experience of ride hailing to the core. Now that having a cab at your location at a click is a norm, there is a further need to make that journey more comfortable in all ways possible. Attempts in this direction can be seen in Shoffr incentivizing their chauffeurs on good behavior with riders rather than just the number of trips they complete. 

4. Signifies the role of emerging technologies like blockchain to meet the needs of today's users, who desire transparency and wish to be in more control of their experiences. In this regard, Drife may be cited as an example for decentralizing the ride hailing experience and promoting open governance for riders and drivers, safeguarding their best interests.

5.  Bears testimony to more sections of society being comfortable with technology, provided it intertwines with their needs and adapts to make itself a part of their lives. 

While Ola and Uber made online ride hailing a norm, new players in this space represent beacons of new possibilities that user experience necessitates.

posts.content:
Premiumisation is rising—but so is inequality. Both tell a story of opportunity.


Rising incomes in India's top 10% is driving a wave of premium consumption. Brands across categories are dipping into this trend to drive value like BluSmart and Shoffr redefining ride-hailing, Tira Beauty, Nappa Dori, and Miraggio in luxury beauty and lifestyle, to name a few.


But while we're talking about increasing share of the premium segment with rising incomes, another trend is emerging in parallel: high inequality.


In metros – Delhi, Mumbai, the Gini coefficient over the last 4 years hovers near 0.4, comparable to some of the highest globally – Sau Paolo, Jo’burg, London —a striking indicator. And where inequality grows, so does demand for protection, privacy, and exclusivity. That’s why sectors like private security, smart home defense, and cybersecurity for individuals are are going to enter the spotlight.


Theft cases in Delhi alone rose steadily (205,545 in 2022 to ~210,000–220,000 estimated for 2023), driven by vehicle thefts (+5%) and house thefts (+20%). Detection rates for thefts are low (e.g., 18.4% for vehicle theft), as is the availability of state police personnel.

If global benchmarks show us a path in regions with rising disparity—Latin America, Africa, and Asia—private security is booming. South Africa’s private security market, valued at ~$4 billion, employs more guards than police, driven by a Gini of 0.63 and high crime rates. Latin America’s security market grows at 8–10% annually due to urban inequality and crime.

With India on a similar trajectory, rapid-response armed services, digital asset protection, and even private investigation services are likely to boom.

The best way to think about monetization in marketplaces (e-commerce, food delivery, ride-sharing) is to view them as a pipe connecting customers at one end to suppliers at the other.

As marketplaces grow, more customers and suppliers enter, but the pipe’s width stays the same, increasing competition for both. This creates monetization opportunities for the platform:

Customer-side monetization:  
1. Priority shipping (Amazon  Prime)  
2. Faster bookings (Urban Company)  
3. Reduced wait times (Swiggy ONE)  
4. Tipping incentives for faster service (Ola)  
5. Personalized recommendations  
6. Exclusive access to limited products or early sales (Flipkart BBD)

Supplier-side monetization:  
1. Paid ads for better visibility  
2. Higher margins for premium listings  
3. Offering exclusive discounts on the platform  
4. Exclusive partnerships with the platform  
5. Advanced analytics for business insights (Zepto)  
6. Pay for better Logistics support and inventory management (Amazon)
7. Avial Financing and insurance plans

However, as the platform grows, competition intensifies, even the 'premium paid' by both customers and suppliers is not sufficient, and it pushes out those who are unwilling to pay. While dominant platforms like Myntra or Ola invest heavily to maintain near-monopoly or duopoly status by focusing on growth
When incumbents start to monetize, offering a different proposition but addressing the same problem statement, new entrants (Shoffr, Rapido, or Zepto) capitalize on dissatisfied customers and suppliers, focusing on again on Growth before monetization, and then the cycle repeats. That’s the beauty of capitalism!

I recently posted about BluSmart 's rise in the ride-hailing space in India. GrowthX® had put out out a very informative YouTube video summarizing the strategy and journey taken. I wanted to follow up on my previous post to cover another major aspect of BluSmart's success in India: Customer Centricity.

BluSmart already had the #usp of being a transportation company with fully-electric vehicles. Done. Getting traction requires solving one or very few small problems for users. They went the airport rides route in major cities like #bangalore #delhi #mumbai. Bangalore in particular has an airport that is far away from the center of the city with no metro service or smooth public bus transport options. If you have a lot of luggage, don't wish to spend 2+ hours using public transport, or need reliability, then you were at the whims of Ola and Uber drivers that may or may not make you sweat at peak times. 

BluSmart basically digitized the private car service on an app as opposed to have to arrange one with a service via telephone or Whatsapp which also comes at a premium price; sometimes 30-50% more than using a ride-hailing app. BluSmart allows your to pick a date and time in advance and the driver always show up on-time and in many instances, earlier than the designated time. This concept doesn't only apply for catching flights; but for any appointment you may have. It comes at a bit of a premium, but it's reliable, consistent, and keeps customers stress-free and happy.

Namma Yatri Rapido are companies in a similar space got the word out by offering a very specific feature that was very customer centric - the ability to name your price above a standard base price for autorickshaws and cabs. Uber Ola didn't offer this option. Users would be at the back and call of surge/demand pricing while not having the option to pay a premium to get a faster ride. Namma Yatri and Rapido offered this option. It was no surprise that Ola followed suit (albeit briefly) with a similar function that went away as fast it came.

The 2.0 of startups or 2.0 of 21st century crucial services is starting to emerge and companies are learning from the mistakes or even apathy from the giants that thrived on a growth-only mindset in 1.0. Interesting times ahead as these later founders and leaders are more visible, have deep experience, clear leadership teams, and are not breaking the bank by "growth at all costs" with long-term planning and finances.

(b) Operating model: Scheduled trips, owned vehicles, driver on payroll etc
(c) Primary route(s): Airport ↔ City center

🍃 There are clear tailwinds:
(i) FAME III subsidy for EV manufacturers will continue (albeit at a lower ₹₹ allocation) per the Interim Budget
(ii) Govt financing for green loans is available (via IREDA, PFC etc)
(iii) Customer “dissatisfaction” with Uber & Ola encourages them to try different vendors / different models (e.g. scheduled vs on-demand)

🧠 The key with these fleets is:
(a) How do you get to unit break even? (i.e. drive high utilization OR premium pricing OR both)
(b) How do you scale from YY to YYY? (i.e. don’t have too many quality issues at x10 scale)
(c) OEM risk? (i.e. will the preferred OEM continue to drop prices? And, will battery life pan out?)

➡ Over the next 10 years, we should see most ICE cab fleets get replaced with such EV cab fleets. Clear winners in OEM segment are visible: Tata Motors & MG Motors India.. Will be exciting to see who wins (on the fleet operator side) in this transition!

Premiumization: Going ahead of basics 🚀

In today’s world, premiumization is all about turning everyday products into exclusive experiences. Consumers want more than just a product; they seek something that aligns with their lifestyle, reflects their values, and offers more than the basics. Brands that nail this don’t just elevate their product—they create entirely new sectors. 🌟

Let’s take Shoffr 🚗—it’s not your average ride-hailing app. Shoffr turned getting from A to B into a luxurious experience, offering premium vehicles, personalized services, and extra comforts that make every ride feel like a treat. It’s no longer just about transportation; it’s about giving customers a taste of the good life with every trip.

Similarly, Mokabora 🧳 didn’t just sell luggage—they redefined travel gear. With high-quality materials, sleek designs, and innovative features, they’ve turned an everyday suitcase into a premium travel companion. Customers aren’t just buying bags; they’re investing in a luxury travel experience.

Then there’s Atomberg 🌪️—a company that took something as basic as ceiling fans and disrupted the market with energy-efficient, smart, and premium designs. While most fans remained the same for decades, Atomberg innovated with brushless DC motors, remote controls, and sleek aesthetics, proving that even a simple home appliance could be premiumized.

Apple 🍎 has done something similar with their tech. From iPhones to MacBooks and AirPods, they’ve turned everyday gadgets into status symbols. The seamless integration of their ecosystem makes each device more than just functional; it’s part of a premium experience that locks you into their world. And Starbucks ☕ did the same thing with coffee—what was once just a regular coffee is now a moment of indulgence. With personalized drinks, cozy vibes, and premium branding, Starbucks turned coffee culture into an exclusive lifestyle.

But here’s the catch: many brands make the mistake of raising prices without adding real value. ❌ When that happens, customers feel they’re being overcharged for ordinary products.

So, what’s the fix? It’s about focusing on quality and creating an experience worth paying for. Look at Dyson’s innovation or Birkenstock’s sustainable comfort—they’ve turned simple products into premium experiences that justify their price. 💸

Premiumization is about delivering value that makes customers feel they’ve made the right choice. When done right, you're not just selling a product—you’re reshaping entire sectors. 💡

Shoffr’s plan to crack the ride-hailing market
*************************************************
As a second mover, Bengaluru-based electric taxi service Shoffr has the advantage of learning from the mistakes of its peers who started out earlier. Having learnt from observation and experience, it intends to do things differently.  
 
A big takeaway for Shoffr—which provides airport transfers, outstation rentals, and city rentals—is the need to focus on higher utilisation of assets, unit economics, and operational efficiency to ensure the business stays sustainable.
 
Competitive landscape:
Shoffr started as a bootstrapped venture, launching with a fleet of four cars. Once the fleet reached a breakeven point of 20-30 cars, the business became self-sustaining, CEO and Co-founder Vikas Bardia says. Today, the company has scaled to around 130-150 cars in Bengaluru and 20-25 in Delhi.

The company’s unique way of fundraising—from its own users and angel investors instead of traditional VC funding, was a way to give early adopters a “chance to participate in the company’s growth”, according to Bardia. While Shoffr is open to VC funding, it’s crucial to find investors who share their vision, he adds. 

Building on the experience of its competitors, Shoffr’s focus is on high utilisation and avoiding expanding too quickly. The company’s asset utilisation is over 75%, which helps keep the business sustainable, Bardia says.
